docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. John G. Rowland announced a plan today to provide health insurance to the state's 88,000 uninsured children by setting up a subsidized health care program for working families. Mr. Rowland called for a special session of the Legislature to act on the plan so that the state can tap Federal funds that become available Oct. 1 and begin the program by Jan. 1.

headline.main: Rowland Proposes Health Plan to Cover 88,000 Uninsured Children

docs.lead_paragraph: Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, urged Congress today to set comprehensive Federal standards to protect the confidentiality of medical records. But she said lawmakers must not ''interfere with the well-established procedures of the criminal justice system.'' In a report to Congress, she said intelligence agencies, as well as law-enforcement officers, should have access to patients' records, unfettered by new restrictions. The proposed exception for intelligence agencies was added to her report at the last minute, at the suggestion of intelligence officials.

headline.main: Limited Access to Medical Records Is Urged

docs.abstract: HEW Sec Donna Shalala urges Congress to set comprehensive Federal standards to protect confidentiality of medical records, but says lawmakers should not interfere with procedures of criminal justice system; photo before Congress; says intelligence agencies and law-enforcement officers should have access to records, in accord with present practice; senators express concerns about privacy (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing like a little sunlight to disinfect a smelly political deal. When forced to act in broad daylight this week, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to rescind a $50 billion tax break that Congress had previously awarded the tobacco industry in stealthy bargaining over tax-cut legislation as part of the balanced-budget deal this summer. The 95-to-3 vote is a measure of the waning clout of the tobacco lobby and a warning that such underhanded deals are apt to backfire once discovered. No one ever owned up to being responsible for the tax giveaway, which was inserted into the legislative package at the last minute without analysis, debate or overt sponsorship. But most reports blame the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich for engineering the tax windfall and fault the Clinton Administration for acquiescing. Whatever the case, the episode provides yet another example of slippery behavior by the well-heeled tobacco lobby and its minions in Congress.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes than, when forced to act in broad daylight, Senate rescinded $50-billion tax break for tobacco industry; says 95-to-3 vote shows waning clout of tobacco lobby, and that there is nothing like sunlight to disinfect smelly political deal that would have undercut proposed tobacco industry settlement with states (S)
docs.snippet: There is nothing like a little sunlight to disinfect a smelly political deal. When forced to act in broad daylight this week, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to rescind a $50 billion tax break that Congress had previously awarded the tobacco industry...

docs.lead_paragraph: A computer network that links hospitals, doctors' offices and insurance companies will go on line in New York City during the next three months at the four Manhattan hospitals affiliated with New York University, according to a health industry group that designed the system. The group, comprising the Greater New York Hospital Association and four insurance companies -- Group Health Inc., Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and BRC Health Care of Dallas -- has spent more than two years developing the computer system, which it said would provide instantaneous transfer of patient records, X-rays and insurance forms.

headline.main: Metro Business; Network for Health Data

docs.lead_paragraph: When Bill Clinton stopped at Merck & Company's old headquarters in Rahway, N.J., during the 1992 Presidential campaign, it was not for an entirely friendly visit. The campaign was gearing up that September and Mr. Clinton, promising a revolution in health care, had come to one of the citadels of the pharmaceutical industry to call for cost controls on prescription drugs. But Merck, acutely aware of the war on health costs that managed care organizations were already waging, had read the writing on the wall. Just weeks before, it had jumped into the generic drug business, to produce cut-price versions of Merck brands that had lost their patent protection. Other drug giants, including Hoechst A. G., were soon making the same leap, seeing generics as a prudent insurance policy.

headline.main: Cleaning Out The Medicine Cabinet; Prescription Drug Makers Reconsider Generics

docs.abstract: Some of pharmaceutical giants that jumped into generic drug business five years ago in response to price-cutting pressure are abandoning effort; shift reflects both hard-edged nature of generics business and continued high profitability of prescription drugs; graph; table; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''If we act now,'' says Health and Human Services Secretary Donna Shalala in written testimony prepared for a Senate hearing today, ''we still have a golden opportunity to safeguard our age-old right to privacy in a brave new world of computers and biology. Nowhere is that more important than with our most personal information, our family secrets: our medical records.'' Not many Americans would disagree with the Secretary that private medical records are unusually sensitive. Nor would they dispute the need for strong legal safeguards to limit access to and the possible abuse of psychiatric, genetic and other data. Unfortunately, the Administration's proposal on medical privacy, which Ms. Shalala will unveil, is dangerously defective. In an effort to assist investigations into suspected medical and insurance fraud, it would grant police officers broad access to patients' medical records, with scant restrictions on how the information gets distributed and used. This violates fundamental notions of privacy.
docs.abstract: Editorial opposes Clinton Administration's proposal on medical privacy, which would grant police broad access to patients' medical records, with scant restrictions on how information is distributed and used, to assist investigations into suspected medical and insurance fraud (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many large health maintenance organizations are placing new restrictions on doctors' use of the controversial weight-loss drugs fen-phen and Redux and are declining to reimburse patients who obtain prescriptions for the medications through commercial weight-loss centers or by other means. The new limits are a response by the managed care companies to the increasing concerns and publicity about potentially fatal side effects of the diet pills. Some of the largest H.M.O.'s in the country are reconsidering their policies regarding these drugs, with some taking more aggressive steps than others.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Move to Restrict Use of Diet Pills by Members

docs.lead_paragraph: Columbia/HCA Warns Earnings Will Be Lower The Government inquiry into Columbia/HCA Healthcare and stagnant business at its 342 hospitals will push third-quarter earnings at the troubled health care provider down. The company said that per-share earnings would drop to 20 cents or 25 cents, compared with 46 cents in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts were surprised by the company's announcement; they had predicted that earnings would exceed 50 cents a share. Columbia shares fell 9 percent. $(Page D5.$)
docs.snippet: Columbia/HCA Warns Earnings Will Be Lower  The Government inquiry into Columbia/HCA Healthcare and stagnant business at its 342 hospitals will push third-quarter earnings at the troubled health care provider down. The company said that per-share...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that stagnant business at its 342 hospitals, as well as costs stemming from Federal fraud inquiries, would drag down profits in its third quarter. Columbia/HCA, based in Nashville, said that per-share earnings would drop to 20 cents or 25 cents, compared with 46 cents in the quarter a year earlier, mainly because of a 1 percent decline in August in admissions to hospitals the company has owned for at least a year.

headline.main: Columbia/HCA Says Its 3d-Quarter Earnings Will Fall

docs.abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says stagnant business at its 342 hospitals, as well as costs stemming from Federal fraud inquiries, will drag down profits in third quarter; news surprises analysts; Columbia also says it will take $60 million charge against earnings in quarter, primarily to cover payments to teams of lawyers and accountants who are marshaling defense records to use in negotiations with Federal investigators (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bowing to Federal and state law-enforcement authorities, Clinton Administration officials will soon propose legislation that would allow police officers to gain broad access to patients' medical records, with hardly any restrictions on use or redisclosure of the data. While law-enforcement authorities frequently negotiate access to such materials now, the Administration recommends that health care providers and those who pay for such care be explicitly ''permitted to disclose health information without patient authorization'' when the records are sought by Federal or state investigators.

headline.main: Plan Would Broaden Access Of Police to Medical Records

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration, bowing to Federal and state law-enforcement authorities, will propose legislation that would allow police investigators to gain broad access to patients' medical records, with hardly any restrictions on use or further disclosure of data; recommends that health care providers and those for pay for care be explicitly permitted to disclose information without patient authorization when records are sought by Federal or state investigators; proposal is linked to probes of fraud in giant health care industry; Administration would also limit access by employers, researchers, drug and marketing companies and others, with civil and criminal penalties for violations (M)
